description: colorful image of woman in bathtub filled with blue water and bubbles, eyes closed, lathering her hair with both hands at R side of image; silver/gray tiles on wall in upper half of image; towel, razer, shampoo bottle on edge of tub toward bottom of image; pigment of tiles and water has iridescent sheen; floating mount in white wood frame
markings: verso BL, graphite: \"Bather Washing Her Hair\"; verso BR, barely legible, in graphite: woman washing / her hair; Eric Firestore gallery label on back of frame at TL
text: Helen Oji’s intimate self-portrait, Bather Washing Her Hair, 1974, was created at a moment when Oji was finding her voice as an artist, an American woman, and a third-generation Japanese American. When considered within the history of Japanese and Euro-American depictions of Asian women bathing, this self-portrait holds particular power. The privacy and comfort of Oji’s bath is deliberately unerotic; the angle of her thigh is not for the viewer’s pleasure, but for shaving.Through frank self-depiction and a rejection of any sexualized content in her portrait in favor of self-empowerment.
title: Bather Washing her Hair
